skill.name: global-validation
skill.description: Implement comprehensive server-side validation with allowlists, type checking, input sanitization, and consistent error messages, while using client-side validation for user experience. Use this skill when validating user input, form data, API requests, implementing security checks, preventing injection attacks, checking data types/formats/ranges, or providing validation feedback. Apply when working with form validation, API endpoint validation, input sanitization, business rule enforcement, or any code that accepts and validates external data to ensure security, data integrity, and proper user feedback across all entry points.

No executable code, network operations, or file system access beyond normal file reading exists.

content.value_statement: This skill provides comprehensive validation patterns for user input, API requests, and form data. It helps prevent injection attacks, ensures data integrity, and delivers consistent error feedback to users.
actual_capabilities: Implement server-side validation with allowlists for security
Perform type checking, format validation, and range checks
Sanitize input to prevent SQL injection, XSS, and command injection
Create consistent and user-friendly validation error messages
Apply validation consistently across all API entry points
Implement both server-side and client-side validation patterns

Does not provide runtime validation for specific data formats
Requires manual implementation of validation logic in target code

use_cases.title: Secure API Endpoint Development
use_cases.description: Apply server-side validation to API routes, checking types, formats, and business rules before processing requests. Prevent injection attacks and ensure data integrity.

use_cases.title: Form Validation Implementation

use_cases.target_user: Full-stack developers working on web applications

use_cases.title: Security Code Review
use_cases.description: Review existing code for input validation vulnerabilities. Identify missing validation, weak sanitization, and inconsistent error handling patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Basic API Validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Add validation to this API endpoint that checks: required fields are present, data types are correct, values are within expected ranges, and returns user-friendly error messages for each validation failure.

prompt_templates.title: Injection Prevention
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code for injection vulnerabilities. Add input sanitization to prevent SQL injection, XSS, and command injection. Use allowlist validation where possible and escape input for high-risk contexts.

prompt_templates.title: Form Validation Layer
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a validation layer for this form that includes: client-side validation for immediate feedback, server-side validation for security, and consistent error messages that help users correct their input.

prompt_templates.title: Business Rule Validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Add business rule validation to this function. Check for conditions like sufficient balance, valid date ranges, and logical constraints. Return clear error messages that explain why validation failed.

output_examples.input: User registration API endpoint that accepts name, email, and password
output_examples.output: Validation added: name must be non-empty string (1-100 chars), email must match email format regex, password must be 8+ chars with complexity requirements. Returns specific error: 'email' => 'Invalid email format' or 'password' => 'Password must contain at least 8 characters including uppercase, lowercase, and number'.

output_examples.input: SQL query builder with user-provided column names
output_examples.output: Implemented allowlist validation: only columns in ALLOWED_COLUMNS can be used. Rejected with error: 'Invalid sort field. Allowed fields are: id, name, created_at'. This prevents SQL injection via column name manipulation.

best_practices: Always validate on the server side, even with client-side validation for user experience
Use allowlists (whitelists) instead of denylists for validation patterns
Return specific, actionable error messages that help users correct their input
anti_patterns: Relying solely on client-side validation for security
Using denylists to filter input instead of allowlists
Exposing sensitive validation logic or internal error details to users

faq.question: What is the difference between validation and sanitization?
faq.answer: Validation checks if input meets expected criteria and rejects invalid data. Sanitization cleans or escapes input to remove dangerous content. Both are needed: validation rejects bad data, sanitization makes remaining data safe to use.

faq.question: Should I validate on client-side or server-side?
faq.answer: Validate on both. Client-side validation improves user experience with immediate feedback. Server-side validation provides security and data integrity since client-side checks can be bypassed.

faq.question: What is allowlist validation?
faq.answer: Allowlist validation defines what is permitted and rejects everything else. This is more secure than denylists because new attack patterns can bypass denylists. Only accept known-good values.

faq.question: How do I validate user input without being too restrictive?
faq.answer: Balance security with usability. Use strict validation for security-critical data (passwords, amounts). Use reasonable ranges for other data. Test with real user data to adjust limits.

faq.question: What error messages should I show users?
faq.answer: Show specific, actionable messages. Say 'Email must include @ symbol' not 'Invalid input'. Avoid technical details that could help attackers. Guide users to correct their input.

faq.question: Does this skill generate validation code?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides guidance patterns and best practices for implementing validation. You apply these patterns when writing code that adds validation to your specific use case.
